City and nation react after Marathon attack

Flowers, a teddy bear, and messages were among the items left at one barricade. Stan Honda/AFP/Getty Images
Runner Megan Cloke paused after leaving flowers on the step of bombing victim Martin Richard's home. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Martin Richard, 8, of Dorchester, was one of the victims of Monday's bombings. Courtesy of Richard family
Boston College senior Marissa Irwin, a marathoner, left a flower at a police barricade. Matthew Cavanaugh/EPA
Boston police commissioner Ed Davis spoke during a morning news conference. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
Traders at the New York Stock Exchange observed a moment of silence this morning. Richard Drew/Associated Press
A guardsman checked identification at a roadblock near the crime scene. Spencer Platt/Getty Images
Bags of belongings were sorted out near the Boston Marathon's finish line. Justin Lane/EPA
A pedestrian walked past abandoned tables at Stephanie's on Newbury this morning. Matthew Cavanaugh/EPA
The front page of today's Chicago Tribune sports section paid tribute to Boston's sports teams.
MIT's Green Building was illuminated with an image of the American flag overnight. Matthew J. Lee / Globe Staff
Authorities searched an apartment complex overnight on Revere Beach Parkway as part of the investigation. Matthew J. Lee / Globe Staff
Law enforcement officials are seen leaving the apartment complex in Revere, which is a part of the investigation. Getty Images

— Chris, Quincy, Ill.
